    Complicated Copulas

    Chase Mathis

    2025-07-31

    Complicated-Copulas.Rmd
    library(survivl)
library(dplyr)
library(ipw)
library(broom)
library(knitr)
library(dplyr)
library(survival)

    This vignette will discuss the different ways a user can specify the dependence structure between the outcome variable and covariates with increasing copmlexity.

    A Simple Example

    This example mimics the example in Examples.Rmd. We specify the copula as the last argument in the formulas list as a list itself. We specify that YY, the outcome, has a copula with our time-varying covariate ZZ only. The last entry in the family variable specify that this is a Gaussian copula and the last entry in the parameters list gives the beta value for the linear value.

    Mathematically, for j,k∈{0,1,2,3,4,5,6}2j,k \in \{0,1,2,3,4,5,6\}^2 the dependence between Yj,ZkY_j, Z_k is the same and it is a gaussian copula with parameter rho=0.4rho = 0.4.

    formulas <- list(C ~ 1,
                 Z ~ X_l1 + C,
                 X ~ Z_l0 + C,
                 Y ~ X_l0 + C,
                 list(Y = list(Z ~1)))
family <- list(5,1,5,3,1)
link <- list("logit", "identity", "logit", "inverse")
pars <- list(C = list(beta=0),
             Z = list(beta = c(-1/2,1/2,0.25), phi=0.5),
             X = list(beta = c(0,1/2,1/10)),
             Y = list(beta = c(0.25,0.5,0.05), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y = list(Z = list(beta=0.8472979))))  # gives correlation 0.4

set.seed(123)
n <- 2e4
surv_model <- survivl_model(T=7, formulas=formulas, family=family, pars=pars, link=link)
dat <- rmsm(n, surv_model)
datl1 <- surv_to_long(dat)

head(cor(datl1 %>% select(T, Z)))
#>          T        Z
#> T 1.000000 0.407914
#> Z 0.407914 1.000000

    Conditional Copulas

    Similar to causl, we can set the dependence between YY and XX to be conditional on some other variables. Here, we set the dependence between YkY_k and ZjZ_j to be a student’s t copula conditional on C,X0C, X_0. Our latent correlation variable η\eta is defined as $\eta_i = 2 * \rm{expit}(0*1 + 0.5*C_i + 0.8472979 * X_{0,i}) - 1$ and for each observation of Yk,ZjY_k, Z_j the correlation parameter is ηi\eta_i.

    formulas <- list(C ~ 1,
                 Z ~ X_l1 + C,
                 X ~ Z_l0 + C,
                 Y ~ X_l0 + C,
                 list(Y = list(Z ~ C + X_0)))
family <- list(5,1,5,3,1)
link <- list("logit", "identity", "logit", "inverse")
pars <- list(C = list(beta=0),
             Z = list(beta = c(-1/2,1/2,0.25), phi=0.5),
             X = list(beta = c(0,1/2,1/10)),
             Y = list(beta = c(0.25,0.5,0.05), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y = list(Z = list(beta=c(0, 0.5, 0.8472979), df = 5))))  

set.seed(123)
n <- 2e4
surv_model <- survivl_model(T=7, formulas=formulas, family=family, pars=pars, link=link)
dat <- rmsm(n, surv_model)
datl2 <- surv_to_long(dat)

head(cor(datl2 %>% select(T, Z)))
#>           T         Z
#> T 1.0000000 0.3426135
#> Z 0.3426135 1.0000000

    Multiple Time Varying Covariates

    This example includes multiple time-varying confounders. We have both Z1Z1 and Z2Z2 and therefore need to model the dependence between YY and Z1Z1 and between YY and Z2∣Z1Z2 \mid Z1. The ordering of this is natural from the order of the time-varying covariates.

    Previously, we had the same copula for all time steps tt, but now we are specifying a markov formula for the copula like the other formulas. So, the dependency between YkY_k and Z2jZ2_j is conditioned on Z1jZ1_j.

    n <- 2e4
formulas <- list(C ~ 1,
                 list(Z1 ~ X_l1 + C,Z2 ~ X_l1 + Z1_l0),
                 X ~ Z1_l0 + Z2_l0 + C,
                 Y ~ X_l0 + C,
                 list(Y = list(Z1 ~1, Z2 ~ Z1_l0)))
family <- list(5,c(5,1),5,3,c(1,1))
link <- list("logit", c("logit","identity"), "logit", "inverse")
pars <- list(C = list(beta=0),
             Z1 = list(beta = c(-1/2,1/2,0.25), phi=0.5),
             Z2 = list(beta = c(0, -1/4, 2/5), phi = 0.65),
             X = list(beta = c(0,1/4, 1/2,1/10)),
             Y = list(beta = c(0.25,0.5,0.05), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y = list(Z1 = list(beta= 0.847), Z2 = list(beta=c(0.5,0.847))))) 

set.seed(123)
surv_model <- survivl_model(T=7, formulas=formulas, family=family, pars=pars, link=link)
dat <- rmsm(n, surv_model)
datl3 <- surv_to_long(dat)

cor(datl3 %>% select(T, Z1, Z2))
#>            T        Z1        Z2
#> T  1.0000000 0.1756963 0.1679412
#> Z1 0.1756963 1.0000000 0.2239408
#> Z2 0.1679412 0.2239408 1.0000000

    Conditioning on Treatments

    In addition to conditioning on other time-varying covariates, the user can also condition on past treatments. This example extends on our previous, but now the dependence between Z1jZ1_j and YkY_k depends on Xj−1X_{j-1} and the dependence between YkY_k and Z2jZ2_j depends on Z1jZ1_j (like before) and on X0X_0. This has a lot of moving parts and a probably over-complicated model, but its meant to illustrate the flexiblity of the copula construction.

    n <- 2e4
formulas <- list(C ~ 1,
                 list(Z1 ~ X_l1 + C,Z2 ~ X_l1 + Z1_l0),
                 X ~ Z1_l0 + Z2_l0 + C,
                 Y ~ X_l0 + C,
                 list(Y = list(Z1 ~X_l1, Z2 ~ Z1_l0 + X_0)))
family <- list(5,c(5,1),5,3,c(1,1))
link <- list("logit", c("logit","identity"), "logit", "inverse")
pars <- list(C = list(beta=0),
             Z1 = list(beta = c(-1/2,1/2,0.25), phi=0.5),
             Z2 = list(beta = c(0, -1/4, 2/5), phi = 0.65),
             X = list(beta = c(0,1/4, 1/2,1/10)),
             Y = list(beta = c(0.25,0.5,0.05), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y = list(Z1 = list(beta= c(0,0.847)), 
                                           Z2 = list(beta=c(0, 0.5,0.847)))))

set.seed(123)
surv_model <- survivl_model(T=7, formulas=formulas, family=family, pars=pars, link=link)
dat <- rmsm(n, surv_model)
datl4 <- surv_to_long(dat)

cor(datl4 %>% select(T, Z1, Z2))
#>             T         Z1        Z2
#> T  1.00000000 0.04075901 0.1091441
#> Z1 0.04075901 1.00000000 0.2209887
#> Z2 0.10914409 0.22098871 1.0000000

    Verifying The Correct Marginal Quantity

    We can estimate the marginal causal quantity $p(y \mid \rm{do}(X))$ with IPW. We calculate the models and print the estimates at the end. All estimates are within 2 s.es.

    
# Compute IPW weights
ipw_weights <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial", # all of our treatments are binary
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~C,
  denominator = ~Z,
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = datl1
)
datl1$wt <- ipw_weights$ipw.weights
sumY1 <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X + C, data = datl1, timefix = FALSE, id =id,
              weight = wt)


# Compute IPW weights
ipw_weights <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial", # all of our treatments are binary
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~C,
  denominator = ~Z,
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = datl2
)
datl2$wt <- ipw_weights$ipw.weights
sumY2 <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X + C, data = datl2, timefix = FALSE, id =id,
              weight = wt)
    # Compute IPW weights
ipw_weights <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial", # all of our treatments are binary
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~C,
  denominator = ~Z1 + Z2,
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = datl3
)
datl3$wt <- ipw_weights$ipw.weights
sumY3 <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X + C, data = datl3, timefix = FALSE, id =id,
              weight = wt)

# Compute IPW weights
ipw_weights <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial", # all of our treatments are binary
  link = "logit",
  numerator = ~C,
  denominator = ~Z1 + Z2,
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = datl4
)
datl4$wt <- ipw_weights$ipw.weights
sumY4 <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X + C, data = datl4, timefix = FALSE, id =id,
              weight = wt)
    Cox Model Results for sumY1 - sumY4
    Model term estimate std.error statistic p.value
    Model 1 X -0.507 0.015 -33.186 0.000
    Model 1 C -0.032 0.014 -2.126 0.033
    Model 2 X -0.516 0.015 -33.771 0.000
    Model 2 C -0.024 0.014 -1.637 0.102
    Model 3 X -0.512 0.014 -34.022 0.000
    Model 3 C -0.050 0.014 -3.259 0.001
    Model 4 X -0.508 0.014 -33.784 0.000
    Model 4 C -0.059 0.014 -3.891 0.000
